content: the one that was my own favorite when learning this cast-on was a blog post by talena winters which features both video and photo explanations https //www talenawinters com/super-stretchy-cast-on/ more on german short row why this type of short row i find that german short row are easy to do and leave very little trace in the finished object that said nothing stops you from substituting this technique for another short row technique of your choice just be careful to get your stitch counts right if you use wrap and turn techniques that tend to involve two stitches one wrapped and one slipped when the german short row described here only uses one things to be aware of with german short row there s not much really this is an easy technique to perform once you get the hang of it the main thing to remember is to keep the turn stitch pulled tight which means you should make sure to knit or purl the first stitch after it tightly too still confused i have a couple of videos of this one too in my instagram highlights it is a pretty common technique so finding other explanations online will not be difficult more on kitchener stitch why grafting there are other ways of closing a toe but grafting is the most discrete one when done right it looks exactly like the knit fabric around it and is entirely smooth the smoothness is why it is preferred for this pattern we want to avoid edges that can annoy a pair of little feet this is especially important for kids that will wear their socks in shoes things to be aware of when doing kitchener stitch grafting kitchener stitch is not difficult but to get that perfectly smooth look you will need to pull the yarn to a gauge that matches your knitting as always practice makes perfect and yes of course
